III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section Intervention standards and prohibitions
Description (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a youth's
background or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats,
ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Allegation 1:
On 08/03/2025, Youth A was having suicidal ideation while at the
facility. Staff 1 told Youth A to go into her room and kill herself.
Allegation 2:
On 8/16/2025, Staff 5 told Youth A that she was going to send
someone to New Directions to hurt Youth A due to Youth A
threatening to "beat/kill" another youth at the facility.
Investigation Allegation 1:
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility in collaboration with MDHHS Worker on 8/14/2025.
Chief Administrator (CA) stated Youth A returned back to the
agency on 8/13/2025 after receiving inpatient treatment. CA stated
when Youth A was living with her mother, her mother would
threaten to kill herself in front of Youth A. Youth A makes suicidal
threats often. Another youth went to the hospital a couple days
prior, and this may have triggered Youth A’s behaviors. Youth A
has been at the facility since 4/9/2025. CA does not have any
concerns with Staff 1.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility in
collaboration with MDHHS on 8/14/2025. Youth A stated she
does not like it at New Directions. She stated on 8/3/2025, she
woke up already upset from a fight she had with Youth C the night
prior. Youth A stated on 8/2/2025, she was missing her
grandfather and was soaking her feet and Youth C was being
disrespectful to one of her favorite staff, Supervisor 2. Youth C
was standing on a chair and when she jumped off the chair, she
hit one of the staff in the stomach. Youth C stated she wanted to
die, and Youth A told her she didn’t start saying that until she,
2

Youth A, did. She stated Youth C then tried to run after Youth A
twice because Youth A called Youth C a “cracker”. Youth A stated
she began to fight Youth C, and Youth D jumped into the fight.
Youth A stated on 8/3/25, Staff 4, Supervisor 1, Youth D and
herself were in the salon. Supervisor 1 told Youth A she could not
be in the salon due to being on restrictions from the fight with
Youth C and Supervisor 1 called for a group meeting. Youth A
stated her hair was greasy, and Supervisor 1 told her she would
need to wash her hair in the shower. Youth A told Supervisor 1
she would throw a speaker at her, and she asked to go to the
hospital because she was having suicidal thoughts. Supervisor 1
stated to Youth A that she would get someone to take her, but
Youth A stated Supervisor 1 was lying and that made her more
upset. Youth A stated she went in her room to grab her phone
cord to wrap this around her neck. Youth A then located a USB
cord to wrap around her neck. She came out of her room with the
cord wrapped around her neck and Staff 1 told her to go in her
room “and do that”. Youth A stated that Staff 1’s comment to “go
in your room and do that”, she assumed Staff 1 was telling her to
wrap the cord around her neck in her bedroom and to kill herself.
Youth A stated this made her more upset, so she ran to the back
exit sunroom door and pushed on the door handle, and when the
door opened, she ran outside and went to a neighbor’s house.
She stated Staff 2 and Staff 4 were following her and told Youth A
they would take her to the police station. Youth A stated they were
trying to get her back to the facility, so she ran across the street to
the police station. She stated she wrapped the cord around her
neck at the police station and the police transferred her to a local
hospital where she stayed for three days and then was transferred
to inpatient treatment. Youth A stated Staff 1 and her have a “love-
hate” relationship. On 8/13/2025, Staff 1 was nice to Youth A but
there have been a few times she was not nice to her. Youth A
stated a few weeks ago, Supervisor 1 told her she can’t get her
hair braided because she is white and Supervisor 1 won’t pay for
white or mix youth to get their hair done. She stated she does not
feel safe living at the facility and staff favor people. She stated she
can talk to her foster care worker when she is not feeling safe, her
old foster mother, CA and Supervisor 3 and Staff Senior.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility in
collaboration with MDHHS on 8/14/2025. Youth B stated the
facility has good staff and staff are nice. Youth B stated she likes
to listen to music. She could not recall if any youth had not been at
the facility in the past few days. She feels safe at the facility. For
discipline at the facility, youth names are put on a board, and
3

outings are withheld. Due to Youth B’s cognitive level, no further
information was provided.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility in
collaboration with MDHHS on 8/14/2025. She stated on
8/2/2025, Youth A called her a “cracker” and she brushed it off
then said to Youth A, “at least I’m not a cracker” and gave Youth A
a mean look. She then told Youth A to go back to soaking her feet.
She stated Youth A became mad and she fought her. She had two
scratches on her neck due to Youth A digging her nails into her
and Youth D jumped in. She does not recall how it ended or the
staff names who broke up the fight.
Youth C stated on 8/3/2025, she was in her bedroom and saw
Youth A passing by her room, “like 100 times”. Youth A was
running around “like crazy” trying to leave the facility. She did not
see anything in Youth A’s hand. Youth C was not in the dayroom
to hear if Staff 1 made any comments to Youth A. Youth C stated
there is nothing she likes at New Directions. She stated she keeps
getting into fights and sometimes she doesn’t start them and
sometimes she will say something that will “tick” that person off.
She stated then that person will attempt to fight with her.
Youth C stated for discipline, a youth’s name is added on a board
and are then unable to participate in outings. Youth C stated
Supervisor 1 previously told Youth A and her that they can’t get a
weave in their hair because they are white and white people’s hair
are softer and have a different texture. Youth C could not recall
when the statement was made by Supervisor 1.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility in
collaboration with MDHHS on 8/14/2025. Youth D stated the
facility is a nice place and Youth D gets to go places, receives
money for chores, watches television, and isn’t forced to do
anything. There isn’t anything she doesn’t like about this facility.
Youth D stated Youth A is “pretty cool” and “funny”. She stated
Youth A went to the hospital and returned on 8/13/2025. Youth D
stated on 8/3/2025, she saw Youth A run away from the facility.
She recalls Youth A stating she was going to kill herself and Youth
B stated to her, “Girl stop”. Youth A then smiled and wrapped a
cord around her neck, walked away and went into her room to get
something, but Youth B did not know what. Youth A came out of
her room, went to the back exit door and pushed on the door until
it opened, and Youth A left the facility. Youth D was unable to see
if Youth A had a cord around her neck. Youth D stated the exit
door has a beeping sound when you push on it. Youth D said she
was sitting on the couch and did not want to get involved. She
4

does recall Staff 1 being there. She stated she does not know if
Staff 1 said anything to Youth A. Youth D stated Staff 1 is “pretty
awesome, funny and fun to be around”. There is nothing she
doesn’t like about Staff 1. Youth D stated Youth A told her staff
are not fair and treat other kids special. Youth A also told her Staff
1 told her to go into her room and wrap something around her
neck instead of the phone cord. Youth B stated Youth A told her
this today while Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services (MDHHS) and Department of Child Welfare Licensing
(DCWL) were interviewing other youths.
Youth D then stated later on in this interview, that she did hear
Staff 1 tell Youth A to go wrap something around her neck instead
of the phone cord. She stated this was said when Staff 1 was at
the front desk, and Youth A walked up to the front desk and
wrapped the phone cord around her neck. Youth D stated she was
not honest in the beginning of the interview because she did not
want to get Staff 1 into any trouble. She stated Youth A says she
will kill herself often because she wants attention or for things to
go her way. Youth D stated two weeks ago, Youth A, Youth C and
herself all got into a fight. She stated Youth C was disrespecting
staff and stating she didn’t want to take her medications. Youth C
then kicked staff. She stated she did put her hands on Youth C,
however, when staff told her to stop fighting, she let Youth C go.
Youth D could not recall which staff told her to stop fighting and
which staff broke up this fight. She stated her name was written on
the board as a result of the fight. She stated Youth A had told her
Supervisor 1 told Youth A and Youth C they can’t get their hair
done because they are white. Youth D could not recall when this
occurred.
Case Manager was interviewed face-to-face at the facility in
collaboration with MDHHS on 8/14/2025. On 8/3/2025, Case
Manager stated she received a phone call that Youth A was
AWOL (absent without official leave). She was informed Youth A
had AWOL and she was in the neighborhood on someone’s
porch. She spoke to Youth A on the phone and Youth A stated
she was going to kill herself. Case Manager reminded Youth A
she had court on Tuesday and would be going to camp soon.
Case Manager was trying to remind Youth A that there were
upcoming events that she was excited for. Youth A stated staff
were not listening to her, she is going AWOL and then she hung
up the phone. Case Manager stated Youth A has a history of
AWOL and wanting to kill herself when she feels like she is going
to get in trouble. Youth A has done this several times. During one
of her AWOL’s, Youth A was screaming the word “rape” to anyone
5

who walked by and when Case Manager asked her why she
would use that term, Youth A stated she’s “that type of girl”. Case
Manager stated on 8/11/2025, she was on a phone call with staff
from the inpatient treatment hospital, Youth A’s foster care worker,
the foster care supervisor and Youth A. Youth A stated on the
phone call that Staff 1 told her to go in her room and “do that” and
when Youth A asked Staff 1 to do what, Staff 1 told Youth A to go
ahead and put the cord around her neck and kill herself. When
asked if Staff 1 actually said that, Youth A denied it and said Staff
1 told her to go into her room and “do that in there”. Youth A
denied Staff 1 told her to kill herself. Youth A stated on the phone
call that staff are racist because they won’t let her get her hair
done. Youth A stated on 8/3/2025 she was supposed to get her
hair done by Staff 4 but because of a fight on 8/2/2025, she was
put on restrictions by Supervisor 1.
Therapist was interviewed face-to-face at the facility in
collaboration with MDHHS on 8/14/2025. Therapist stated she
had a session with Youth A on 7/31/2025. Youth A wanted to talk
to her family, however, she would not listen to the reasons why
that was not feasible at that time. Therapist stated when Youth A
doesn’t want to listen and understand, this is a sign Youth A will
begin acting out negatively soon. On 8/1/2025, Youth A asked to
speak to her foster care worker, and she was able to
communicate with her. On 8/2/2025, she received a call from
Youth A to try to bring her back to positive thinking. Therapist has
spoken to Youth A numerous times of what it will take to speak to
her family due to parental rights being terminated. She stated on
7/31/2025, another youth went to the hospital, and this may have
been a trigger for Youth A. Therapist stated Youth A’s depression
and suicidal ideation was scored high on the depression screener.
Therapist feels Youth A is going to act out again as she is not
willing to think positively. Youth A does not feel like she needs to
do anything different. Therapist also stated that on either
7/31/2025 or 8/1/2025, Youth A did tell her that she respected her,
but therapy is not helping her.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility in

7

She stated she was not present for the fight on 8/2/2025,

She stated after group, she went back to her office and then it was

Staff 2 and Staff 4 eventually were able to get Youth A to walk

• Suicide Watch Procedures (Protective Status) Policy: New
Directions' Order of Call requires that a member of the
clinical team or a member of the management team be
contacted immediately when a resident makes a suicidal
gesture, attempt, threat, reference to suicide, or injures
themselves in a deliberate way. The staff person observing
the self-injurious behavior (SIB), suicide attempt/threat will
complete an incident report.
The therapist or Clinical Services Supervisor (after hours)
assesses the acuity of the risk present in the situation and
will issue directions to be followed. The clinician who
completes the acuity assessment will use a standardized
assessment form that will be attached to the incident report
documenting the suicide or self-harm ideation or attempt. If
the acuity level warrants assessment by local mental health
authorities, the resident is transported to the closest
hospital emergency room via staff or via police/ambulance
if required by the situation.
o In some instances, residents will require hospitalization. In
these cases, the Clinical Services Supervisor and the
assigned residential therapist assists to facilitate the
hospitalization. In other situations, residents will remain at
New Directions under Suicide Precaution. Residents are re-
assessed for change in risk/ acuity level no less than every
24 hours by a designated clinician. If the resident continues
to pose a risk after 48 hours, the Clinical Services
Supervisor will reach out to the consulting psychiatrist or
engage an external psychiatric assessment of the resident.
Residents placed on Suicide Precaution are to be
monitored by being kept within constant eyesight of the
staff person assigned to monitor the resident. Normally
residents on suicide watch will remain in the day room.
Staff assigned to suicide precaution must chart every 15-
minutes on the location, mood, and any unusual behavior
of the resident. Suicide observation checklists are to be
given to the youth's clinician. Residents on suicide watch
may not have belts or shoelaces or devices with cords.
Residents remain on suicide precaution until taken off by a
member of the clinical team. Normally, a self-harm contract
